# Question

You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.

Here is a function that should accomplish what you're asking for:

```julia
function extract_julia_code(md::String)
    code_blocks = []
    current_block = IOBuffer()

    for line in eachline(md)
        if startswith(line, "```julia")
            if isopen(current_block)
                push!(code_blocks, String(take!(current_block)))
            end
            current_block = IOBuffer()
        elseif endswith(line, "```") && startswith(line, "```julia")
            print(current_block, line[10:end-3])
            push!(code_blocks, String(take!(current_block)))
            current_block = IOBuffer()
        else
            print(current_block, line)
        end
    end

    if isopen(current_block)
        push!(code_blocks, String(take!(current_block)))
    end

    return join(code_blocks, "\n")
end
```

This function iterates through each line of the input markdown document. When it encounters a code block fence (```julia), it checks if there is already an open code block. If there is, it saves the current code block to the `code_blocks` array and opens a new code block. If there isn't, it just opens a new code block.

When it encounters the end of a code block (```), it saves the current code block to the `code_blocks` array and opens a new code block. If the end fence and the start fence are the same, this means that we have reached the end of the markdown document, and we need to save the last open code block to the `code_blocks` array before returning the result.

Finally, the function returns a single string with all the code blocks joined together with a newline.
